Hello Mike,

For one of our in-house RESTFul application, we started off de=
fining a
domain specific XML vocabulary but ended with a generic XML vocubu=
lary to
describe resources which looks a little similar to what you have
pr=
oposed. One of the major goal of the vocabulary definition was to have the
=
ability to describe all resources in uniform and consistent manner.
Initial=
ly we started designing the vocabulary around the semantics of each
resourc=
e and found out soon that it was harder to maintain. We then decided
to mak=
e a generic "resource" vocabulary i.e. the vocabulary was aimed at to
be ap=
plicable to a large set of resources as possible.

The design considered th=
at anything exposed by our application is a resource
which can be linked an=
d provides links to other relevant resources so we
also included hypermedia=
 controls in the vocabulary similar to what you have
done.

The following i=
s how the vocabulary looks like:

<resource href=3D*"xsd:anyURI"* rel=3D*"r=
els:rel"*/>*    *

*    *

*    *<!-- Links to related resources -->**

*  =
  *<refs>**

*        *<link rel=3D*"rels:rel"* href=3D*"xsd:anyURI"* />**
=

*    *</refs>**

*    *

*    *<!-- Navigational links if listing a large =
collection of resources -->
**

*    *<nav>**

*        *<link rel=3D*"rels=
:next"* href=3D*"xsd:anyURI"*/>**

*        *<link rel=3D*"rels:previous"* =
href=3D*"xsd:anyURI"*/>**

*        *<link rel=3D*"rels:first"* href=3D*"xs=
d:anyURI"*/>**

*        *<link rel=3D*"rels:last"* href=3D*"xsd:anyURI"*/>=
**

*    *</nav>**

*    *

*    *<!-- Include any number of resource prope=
rties here -->**

*    *<!-- Use XSD types -->**

*    *<property name=3D*"=
xsd:string"* type=3D*"xsd:nnn"*></property>**

*    *<property name=3D*"xsd=
:string"* type=3D*"xsd:nnn"*></property>**

*    *

*    *<!-- Use Custom t=
ypes -->**

*    *<property name=3D*"xsd:string"* type=3D*"mytypes:YYY"*></=
property>**

*    *

*    *<!-- Include another resource -->**

*    *<prop=
erty type=3D*"resource"*>**

*        *<resource href=3D*"xsd:anyURI"* rel=
=3D*"rels:rel"*>**

*            *<!-- Include any number of resource prope=
rties here -->**

*            *<property name=3D*"xsd:string"* type=3D*"xs=
d:nnn"*></property>**

*            *<property name=3D*"xsd:string"*
type=
=3D*"xsd:nnn"*></property>*
*

*        *</resource>**

*    *</property>**=


*    *

</resource>**

An example using the above vocabulary is:

<resour=
ce href=3D*"http://mycompany.com/books/fiction"* rel=3D*"rels:fiction"* >
*=
*

*    *

*    *<property name=3D*"description"* type=3D*"xsd:string"*>* B=
rowse Books *
<property>**

*    *

*    *<refs>**

*   *<link href=3D*"htt=
p://abc.com/books/fiction/popular"* rel=3D*"rels:popular"
*/>**

*    *</re=
fs>**

* *

*    *<property type=3D*"resource"*>**

*        *<resource hre=
f=3D*"http://abc.com/books/HGTHG"*
rel=3D*"rels:book"*>*
*

*            *<=
refs>**

*           *<link href=3D*"http://abc.com/books/HGTHG_all"* rel=
=3D*
"rels:related"*/>**

*            *</refs>**

*            *

*       =
     *<property name=3D*"author"* type=3D*"xsd:string"*>*Douglas Adams*
</p=
roperty>**

*            *<property name=3D*"title"* type=3D*"xsd:string"*>=
*Hitch Hiker's
Guide to*</property>*               *

*            *<proper=
ty name=3D*"price"* type=3D*"mytypes:amount"*>*$65*
</property>*           =
              *

*        *

*        *</resource>**

*    *</property>**

=
*    *

*    *<property type=3D*"resource"*>**

*        *<resource href=3D=
*"http://abc.com/books/dirkgently"* rel=3D*
"rels:book"*>*             *

*=
            *<property name=3D*"author"* type=3D*"xsd:string"*>*Douglas Ada=
ms*
</property>**

*            *<property name=3D*"title"* type=3D*"xsd:st=
ring"*>*Dirk Gently
Series*</property>**

*            *<property name=3D*"=
price"* type=3D*"mytypes:amount"*>*$52*
</property>*                       =
  *

*        *</resource>**

*    *</property>**

*    *

*    *<property =
type=3D*"resource"*>**

*        *<resource href=3D*"http://abc.com/books/b=
onecollector"* rel=3D*
"rels:book"*>*              *

*            *<proper=
ty name=3D*"author"* type=3D*"xsd:string"*>*Jeffrey Deaver*
</property>**

=
*            *<property name=3D*"title"* type=3D*"xsd:string"*>*Bone Collec=
tor*
</property>**

*            *<property name=3D*"price"* type=3D*"mytyp=
es:amount"*>*$48*
</property>*                         *

*        *</resou=
rce>**

*    *</property>**

*    *

</resource>**


If I compare the above=
 with HAL, I feel that the above has the advantage of
being more generic, X=
ML schema needn't change when new property needs to be
added etc and all re=
sources will look same structurally. The drawbacks
compared to HAL seems to=
 me that it has more overhead since we have mixed
type information with dat=
a and we can't have schema validation. The
advantages of HAL over the above=
 is that it is more lighter (no type info)
and the XML schema can be valida=
ted. One drawback I see in HAL is that
clients need to have prior knowledge=
 of types.

Appreciate if you could provide your views on the above vocabul=
ary.

Best regards,
Suresh
